title: "Modifying Axes and Scales"

<div id="modifying-axes-and-scales" class="section level1">
<h1>Modifying Axes and Scales</h1>
<div id="axes-and-legends" class="section level2">
<h2>Axes and Legends</h2>
<p>We can modify both axes and legends. <code>ggplot2</code> actually considers these objects to be the same type of object. This means if we learn the tools to work with a legend then we can change the Axes in the same way and vice-verse.</p>
<table style="width:68%;">
<colgroup>
<col width="27%"></col>
<col width="22%"></col>
<col width="18%"></col>
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th align="left">Axis</th>
<th align="left">Legend</th>
<th>Argument Name</th>
</tr>
</thead>

<td align="left">Label</td>
<td align="left">Title</td>
<td><code>name</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">

<td align="left">Key</td>
<td><code>breaks</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td align="left">tick Label</td>
<td align="left">Key Label</td>
<td><code>labels</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
<div id="scales" class="section level2">
<h2>Scales</h2>
<p>Scales are required and included in every plot. If we do not specify them, <code>ggplot2</code> includes them in the background. For example:</p>
<pre><code>geom(data, aes(dep_delay, arr_delay)) +
    geom_point(aes(color=&quot;carrier&quot;))</code></pre>
<p>is read in by <code>ggplot2</code> as :</p>
<pre><code>geom(data, aes(dep_delay, arr_delay))+ 
    geom_point(aes(color=&quot;carrier&quot;)) + 
    scale_x_continuous() + 
    scale_y_continuous() + 
    scale_color_discrete()</code></pre>
<p>Many times we do not need to adjust the scale. This is why they will automatically be included. However if you want to override them, simply fill a scale in the previous scale functions.</p>
<div id="scale-title" class="section level3">
<h3>Scale Title</h3>
<p>The first argument in a scale function is the axes/legend title. We can use 2 types of text:</p>
<ul>
<li>Strings</li>
<li>Mathematical Expressions</li>
</ul>
<p>For example we will create 2 plots below. They will be the same plot but we will allow the first one to just be a string and the second to be a mathematical expression.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>df &lt;- data.frame(x = 1:2, y = 1, z = &quot;a&quot;)
    p &lt;- ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()
    p1 = p + scale_x_continuous(&quot;X axis&quot;)
    p2 = p + scale_x_continuous(quote(a + mathematical ^ expression))
grid.arrange(p1,p2, ncol=2)</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="labeling-a-scale" class="section level3">
<h3>Labeling a Scale</h3>
<p>Earlier we learned about common labeling functions such as:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>xlab</code></li>
<li><code>ylab</code></li>
<li><code>labs</code></li>
</ul>
<p>We can also use common text notations in order to add further details:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>p &lt;- ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) + geom_point(aes(colour = z))
    p1 = p + xlab(&quot;X axis&quot;) + ylab(&quot;Y axis&quot;)
    p2 = p + labs(x = &quot;X axis&quot;, y = &quot;Y axis&quot;, 
                  colour = &quot;Colour\nlegend&quot;)
grid.arrange(p1,p2, ncol=2)</code></pre>
<p>The code above contains <code>&quot;Colour\nlegend&quot;</code>, <code>\n</code> is a shortcode for letting R know that you wish to have a new line. The output of this is shown below.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="breaks-and-labels" class="section level3">
<h3>Breaks and Labels</h3>
<p>We not only like to be able to change the labels of scales but it can be helpful to choose the tick marks as well. The <code>breaks</code> argument controls what values appear as the tick marks on axes and keys.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>df &lt;- data.frame(x = c(1, 3, 5) * 1000, y = 1)
axs &lt;- ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) +
geom_point() +
labs(x = NULL, y = NULL)
axs
axs + scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(2000, 4000))
axs + scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(2000, 4000), labels = c(&quot;2k&quot;, &quot;4k&quot;))</code></pre>
<p>We can see that the above code creates a scatterplot called <code>axs</code> where originally the <code>x</code> and <code>y</code> axes are not labeled and R chooses the tick marks. Then in the second plot we force the tick marks to show at 2000 and 4000. Finally the third plot changes the text at these tick marks.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
<p>As it was state before <code>ggplot2</code> considers axes and legends to be the same type. This means if we are creating a continuous scale with a bar graph coloring or even a heat map we can change the tick marks on the legend as well.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>leg &lt;- ggplot(df, aes(y, x, fill = x)) +
    geom_tile() +
    labs(x = NULL, y = NULL)
leg
leg + scale_fill_continuous(breaks = c(2000, 4000))
leg + scale_fill_continuous(breaks = c(2000, 4000), labels = c(&quot;2k&quot;, &quot;4k&quot;))</code></pre>
<p>We see that just like the axes above we now have three different legends with the tick marks and labels of them changed.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
<p>We can also force different axes to be on a discrete scale rather than continuous.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>df2 &lt;- data.frame(x = 1:3, y = c(&quot;a&quot;, &quot;b&quot;, &quot;c&quot;))
ggplot(df2, aes(x, y)) +
    geom_point()
ggplot(df2, aes(x, y)) +
    geom_point() +
    scale_y_discrete(labels = c(a = &quot;apple&quot;, 
                                b = &quot;banana&quot;, c = &quot;carrot&quot;))</code></pre>
<p>We now change just the tick marks and scale of the y-axis. We can even set the tick marks to be different words.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
<p>There are some more breaks we can do as well as labeling techniques. Reading the <a href="https://www.amazon.com/dp/0387981403/ref=cm_sw_su_dp?tag=ggplot2-20">ggplot book</a> would be worthwhile for more complex graphs.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
